item.title: Helldivers 2 Machinery of Oppression Update Brings Terrifying New Cyborgs and More
item.content:encoded:
Helldivers 2's latest update, Machinery of Oppression, is here, and it sees the return of the Cyborgs to threaten peace and democracy throughout the galaxy, plus a new mission type and more.

As outlined in a Steam news post, Machinery of Oppression sees you and your squad descending into the streets of Cyberstan in order to put a stop to the "collusion of bots and Cyborgs", which threatens the "liberty and sovereignty of Super Earth and its citizens".

You'll be facing three new enemy types in this update: the heavily-armored and tactically-minded Agitators, the terrifyingly quick and aggressive Radicals, and the Vox Engine, a war machine blasting Cyborg propaganda and armed with a battery of laser weaponry.

You'll be facing these new enemies in Helldivers 2's new Cyberstan factory cities map, where you'll be battling through "industrial complexes that are heavily defended with hazards around every corner".

A new mission type, in which you'll be stopping Cyborg production and compromising Automaton defenses, is now available as part of this update, and new objectives include tearing down Cyborg statues anddestroying mega-factories.

Throughout the Machinery of Oppression campaign, Helldivers 2 will track the total number of player deaths, and if the new Galactic Reinforcement Counter reaches zero, then the Battle for Cyberstan has been lost (and, presumably, you won't get any of the fun goodies associated with it).

All of this follows on from the release of the latest Helldivers 2 Warbond, Siege Breakers, which launched earlier this month. You can pick that Warbond up now via the game's store if you want to.

Machinery of Oppression follows Into the Unjust, a major campaign update last year that revolved around the Terminids. As such, it stands to reason that the next big update for Helldivers 2 will probably pit you against the Illuminate. You have been warned.

Helldivers 2's Machinery of Oppression update is available across all platforms now. You can grab the game on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S, and you can read our review of it right here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Remedy Reports Increased Revenue as New CEO Steps Up
item.content:encoded:
Remedy has released its financial statement covering the 2025 fiscal year (which, unlike many other companies, actually spans January through December), and revenue is up just in time for the studio's new CEO to take the reins.

In its latest financial results summary, Remedy says revenue has increased by 17.5% when compared to last year, although profit has fallen. It's a similar story for the final quarter of the year; revenue is up, but profit is down.

Interim CEO Markus Mäki says that Remedy's revenue jump in the fourth quarter can mainly be explained by Alan Wake 2 and Control sales, with the former also generating "meaningful royalties" throughout the year as a whole.

Control has also done pretty well for itself; the game sold over a million copies in 2025 alone, likely driven at least in part by the announcement of sequel Control Resonant at December's Game Awards.

Of course, it hasn't been an entirely positive year for Remedy. In June, the studio released FBC: Firebreak, its multiplayer shooter set in Control's Oldest House, and in August, the studio admitted it was "unsatisfied" with the game's sales to that point.

Indeed, in October, Mäki said Remedy was moving development resources away from FBC: Firebreak and towards other in-development titles, although he also said the studio would "respect [its] communicated roadmap" for the shooter.

Remedy's latest financial statement comes just a day or so after the studio announced the appointment of its new CEO, Jean-Charles Gaudechon, who says he wants to both "protect what makes [Remedy] special" and "scale [the studio] in a way that builds lasting value".

Remedy's board chairman Henri Österlund says Gaudechon, who has worked at companies like EA and CCP Games, is an "excellent fit" for Remedy and that the company is "well-positioned to significantly accelerate growth" under his stewardship.

We'll have to wait and see what Gaudechon brings to Remedy in the coming months and years. Stay tuned for more on this and all other things Remedy-related.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: 2XKO Team Hit by Layoffs as Riot Seeks "a More Sustainable Path"
item.content:encoded:
Riot Games has laid off a number of employees working on the team-based fighting game 2XKO, with the League of Legends and Valorant studio claiming that the game hasn't found an audience big enough to sustain its current team size.

In a news update on its official website, Riot says the decision to reduce 2XKO's team size was made "after a lot of discussion and reflection", and that a "smaller, focused team" will allow Riot to "dig in and make key improvements to the game".

Riot says that 2XKO's expansion from PC to console allowed it to examine "consistent trends in how players were engaging" with the game, and that while a "passionate core audience" loves 2XKO, "overall momentum hasn't reached the level needed" to support the current number of employees.

With regard to the game's direction, Riot says its plans for the 2026 Competitive Series, at least, are "unchanged", and that it will continue to support "events and organizers that already power the FGC (fighting game community)".

2XKO isn't shutting down or being canceled; rather, Riot says these layoffs will allow it to give the game "a more sustainable path forward", and that the studio intends to "continue communicating about how things are progressing".

As to the employees being laid off, Riot says it's provided "a minimum of six months of notice pay and severance" to employees for whom other positions within the organization couldn't be found.

Riot is far from the only studio to lay off employees in recent months. Others include the likes of Ashes of Creation's Intrepid Studios, Tomb Raider outfit Crystal Dynamics, and Amazon Games, to name but a few.

Indeed, these layoffs follow League of Legends staff cuts back in late 2024, so it's not like Riot itself is stranger to letting employees go, even those working on its more successful endeavors.

As for 2XKO, if you'd like to check the fighting game out, you can do so for free right now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S. Stay tuned for more on this and all other things Riot-related.
